text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Kalinda Ukanwa.

I'm an assistant
professor at University

of Southern California
Marshall School of Business.

I'm a quantitative-marketing
scholar.

So if you were to think of an
economist and a statistician,
if they had a baby, that's me.
That's my training.

And in terms of my
area of research,

I actually focus
on the intersection

of artificial intelligence
and notions of responsible use
of artificial intelligence.

I specifically focus
on algorithmic bias
and algorithmic fairness.

And what that
means is, how do we

extract all the benefits of
using artificial intelligence

in our society without creating
some kind of societal harm

in terms of creating outputs
that are fair to everybody?

As somebody who is a woman,
who's a Black woman in society,

I have a personal
interest in ensuring

that the allocation
of resources,

the allocation of outcomes
through artificial intelligence

will work just as
effectively for me
as it would for anybody else.
Why is it important to society?

Because I think everybody
wants to be treated fairly.

It's important and
critical in society,

given that more and
more decisions are

being made by artificial
intelligence every day.

So, for example, it's making
decisions about the loans
you get.

It's making decisions about
the schools you get into.

It's making decisions
about whether or not
you are going to get that job.

These are critical
things, and so we just

want to make sure that, is it
being used in a responsible way?

The analogy I like to use is
the emergence of the automobile.

At one point it was
a new technology.

People were great,
and just said,

now I can get
farther faster than

ever before to the
destinations I want.

Those are the benefits that
came from the automobile.

But at the time that
it was invented,

there weren't such
things as stoplights,
seat belts, et cetera.

Wonderful what the technology
was, but along the way

came to learn there can be
some harms that come from this.
We don't want that.
We want to use that automobile.
We don't want to give it up.

But how do we make it safer,
more usable for everybody

so we can extract
all the benefits?

And I think that's
a great analogy

for what I'm doing with respect
to artificial intelligence.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I believe AI is
good for society.

At the end of the
day, even though I

research about algorithmic
bias and fairness,
I think AI is good for society.

It has so much promise, but
it also has some perils.

We just need to
manage the perils
as we develop the promises.

And so that's where I stand, and
that's where I think AI stands.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Today I'm going to
talk about the impact

of artificial intelligence
and potentially the bias
that it might generate.

How does that impact consumers
in terms of the beliefs
they form about the algorithms?

And could that possibly
spread over a population,

and does that influence
what consumers do in terms
of their decision making?

I'm examining that diffusion
of this unfairness beliefs,
and how does it rise?

Is it always about
a biased algorithm?

And I show conditions
where sometimes it

can rise when the
algorithm is not biased.

And then I look at,
well, what if we

had a third-party
intervention that

is able to report
out to everybody what

the status of the algorithm is
in terms of whether it's biased
or not?

What is the impact on the spread
of beliefs in the consumers,

and what kind of
implications would it

have for firms who are
interacting or providing
services through an algorithm?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

There's so many research
frontiers around here.

I think this question
about the broader
class of responsible AI--

which is an emerging
area of research

that includes questions
about fairness,

questions about
privacy for citizens,

questions about safety
of the algorithm,

questions about accountability,
transparency, trust.

All of that is a
really rich area

for new research,
innovative research,

and it's a
cross-disciplinary nature

because we need to hear from
sociologists, psychologists,

philosophers, ethicists, in
addition to the researchers

that we have now, which is
computer scientists, myself,
and an economist, statistician.

We have those
people, but we need

to hear more from others
on how we need to do this.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I, for sure as a
result of my research,
think there's incentives.

I think there are
economic incentives.
There's legal incentives.

From a legal standpoint,
from a liability standpoint,
firms have incentives.

And that is that
if an algorithm is

found to be discriminatory
to people, of course,

we do have discrimination
laws, and you don't
want to be put in that bucket.
So that's one of--

that's something from a
legal-standpoint incentive.

From an economic standpoint,
over the long run,

it's going to be less profitable
to have an algorithm that
can produce bias.
Why is that?

Because it impacts
what people say.

If it impacts what people
say, they spread it to others,

and over time, people
learn to stay away

from that firm, even
if they are not sure

exactly how the algorithm works,
and that influences demand over

time to a firm that
has a fair algorithm.

And so I show that,
on the short run,

it might be more profitable
to have a biased algorithm,

but in the long run,
it's unprofitable.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

AI is this new
technology that's really

going to innovate and
jump-start and move forward

with leaps and bounds their
organization, their firm.

But I think decision
makers in the room

really need to
think through, OK,

as we use this new
technology, what

are some of the
downstream consequences

and implications that
may come out of that,
and how do we manage that too?

Just don't start up the
new car and just go,

but think about,
OK, how do we avoid
hitting people in the road?

How do we avoid
tumbling off the cliff?

I hope they would think through
those things before deploying.
